reviewText:
This game has everything I like in it. Spaceships, free exploration, trading, mining, missions, and an optional story. If you liked Privateer and always wanted a 2d version of Privateer, that's almost exactly what this game is. And that might be enough for some people.

Unfortunately, the game is lacking polish in many respects. There are plenty of weapons, but aren't enough ships, engines, and shields to really create the kind of ship that will work well in the game. I think that the devs figured players would create these assets using mods, but the only mods out so far are cheaty ones. The economy is a bit off -- ships are a bit too cheap for what they are. There's no ties between resources being available and stations having more products or anything like that.

Piloting needs some work. Colliding with NPCs is far too easy (in fact, it's the only maneuver some NPCs know). Most player ships can't turn fast enough or move their weapons fast enough to target NPCs without themselves striking NPCs.

XP and leveling needs some work. Right now, the only way to level up quickly and easily is to shoot things. You can't level up easily by trading, hacking, or mining, except at the most basic levels. That might be because there are ways to break the system at later points in the game, but that just means that the system is weak and needs polish.

There are distinct periods of boredom in between being able to do things in game. You finish the first couple of missions at level 3 or 4. You can't take on the next storyline mission until Level 10, and can't upgrade ships until Level 15. To get to level 15, you need to clear approximately two low-level systems of pirates. That's a lot of pew pew pew. And it's only reasonable to gain that XP by going pew pew pew, even if you classed as a miner or trader.

I don't know right now if the game will age well and develop a following and some decent mods that will fix these problems. I haven't looked too closely at modding yet. There's a ton of promise here, but unless you're really grabbed by the story, there's very little good reason to play the game past the initial few hours.

reviewText:
I can't really speak to multiplayer as I haven't gotten into it yet but my solo experience thus far has been a lot of fun.

I started out as a fighter, I knew that combat was going to be prevalent no matter where I went so I wanted a little head start in that department. After taking a good look at the skill trees I decided that I actually wanted most if not all of them so throughout my playtime I have been carefully managing what I invest in next. The game can be a little grindy, especially if you've *chosen* to grind as I have, but it's always felt rewarding. Getting that next skill, being able to buy and then use that shiny new hull or weapon or ship upgrade is satisfying.

A lot of zones unfortunately feel a little empty. Filled to the brim with pirates and aliens and in some cases more asteroids than you can mine in half a day, yes, but still empty as from a certain standpoint they're essentially just waypoints to your next stop. Hopefully in the (near) future we'll have more interactivity with these places if the game evolves to a point where we can actually claim and populate them. Extended main storylines to send you to more places would be great, too. All the same, if you're in need of exp or loot to sell it's easy to just pick a zone whose agression level is close to yours and have at it.

Storywise it's pretty solid. You'll have access to a few missions to raise your rep with three of the factions before you actually join any of them. The main quest for the two I've seen are pretty short but well written and the difficulty in terms of how aggressive the zones you'll be visiting is pretty steep so your first playthrough with a new character will feel a lot longer as you level and gear up. There are also missions you can do for the commander at any station you visit. They're selected randomly from a preset list and it's totally up to you if you want to accept them or not. I found that fact to be irritating as I was only really interested in bounty and mining missions, thankfully loudent2 published a mod that allows you access to the whole list so you can just pick the one you want. Much more convenient and a must if you ever get frustrated at the random factor.

There are a lot of items and upgrades to choose from at the beginning, which is awesome, but as you get into the higher levels (I was 146 at the time of writing this... yes I was lazy and copy/pasted my three day old forum post. Deal with it :P) you'll find yourself invariably with the same set of gear as most people; primarily speaking a dark matter generator, a dimensional fuel tank, and either a Hammer or a Death Bringer hull. And lasers. Lots of love for the lasers :).

This is where modding really adds more life to it all. Last week I wanted a (much) shorter range laser that did more damage, I made one. It uses way too much energy imo but I made it, I use it, and so do a few other people now that it's on the Workshop. Then I wanted a rapid fire ballistic weapon that shoots fireballs, made that too. It's a little OP for anything under aggression level 70 or so but it's fun all the same. Got tired of shields, made new armor plating. So my modding skills are amateurish at best but more importantly I'm having a good time doing it, even learned a thing or two about XML along the way. Taking that into consideration, there are a lot of other people writing fantastic mods for the game and publishing them fairly regularly, it's been just over two weeks and there are 50 items in the Workshop already (albeit some of them are translations and don't really affect the core gameplay but I imagine they took a LOT of work and it's quite appreciated to a lot of players). It feels like there's always some cool new user made content to check out and maybe take for a spin. Maybe even share a few of your own ;).

All in all it's a great game. Simple yet very well written, looks fantastic, controls are solid, great support and frequent updates. It has a lot to offer both in terms of content and expandability and it's a lot of fun, right to the point where I started playing one morning and actually forgot to eat anything until mid afternoon. Definitely worth the pricepoint.

reviewText:
VoidExpanse is a top down open world space sandbox game. You play as someone from the Far Colonies who flees from a farm world on a civilian spacecraft, but who that character really is, is up to you. The plot of the game relies on the fact that the Far Colonies are abandoned, after a hostile alien race is discovered. Therefore, it is up to you to fight this threat, if you choose to do so that is. One thing that surprised was the fact that even though this is a simple, yet good looking 2D game, ti has a very detailed video options menu and separate audio sliders, which is a big plus in my book.

Intro:Before being thrown into the procedurally generated universe of VoidExpanse you’re able to create your own character. The game offers a good variety of options such as, hairstyles, accessories and other facial characteristics to customize your character portrait You also have the option to choose one of 9 different classes such as Prospector, Trader, Rogue and Adventurer, each one having their own unique starting bonuses and preassigned skills.

Upon entering the game, if you go on the Character tab you can see your character experience points and skills. Here, you can also access the following categories: piloting, combat, social, industry and engeneering. Each one of these categories has its own unique skill tree which is also affected by the profession you choose during your character creation. That said, I’d recommend you to take your time and examine these and determine which kind of role you want to play. You can be a pirate, a trader, a miner, how you embrance this open universe is entirely up to you. Different skills will have very different applications, some will allow you to persuade certain characters and avoid conflict, others will improve your piloting and mining skills, while others are just required in order to use better gear.

Right next to Character tab, you also have the System Map which is very easy to navigate. It allows you to see the various planets on your current system, asteroids, enemies, space stations as well as jumpgates. It also allows you to set your own navigation points which you can use as destinations for your autopilot. Beware though, your autopilot isn’t smarth enough to avoid pirates and other dangers so make sure you’re actually paying attention to the game while you’re taking advantage of this very helpful feature.

Next up, if you go on the Star System Map, you can see different systems connected by jumpgates and also see each factions territory. If you go to the Factions tab you can see what kind of relations each faction has with one another. There are a total of 6 different factions, including the neutral faction. Each one of these systems has their own characteristics and some might have special events such as gas clouds or debris from past conflicts. Here you can also see each system tech and danger level. The higher the tech level of a system, the better items you can find there and the danger level of a system will affect how difficult are the enemies there.

Of course, as with any space sandbox game, you also have your lovely inventory. Here you can check what items you currently have and see what different modules you have equiped. Still, the only items that you can equip outside a space station are consumables, such as mines and repair kits. Modules such as an engine, generator and shield require you to be inside a space station. It is also on the inventory window that you can check your cargo, this is where you’ll hold various types of goods such as ores and food.

Once you enter a space station you’ll be able to refuel, repair and check various sections of the station. On the hangar you can change your ship parts and on the shop you can buy and sell items. The type of items that are for sale on the shop vary depending on the type of station you’re in. If you’re on a military station you’ll get access to more military gear and if you’re in an outpost you’ll get access to more ships. However, the type of items you’ll find in these shops also depends on the Tech level of the system. Finally, you can also go to the station decks. Here you’ll find people from various factions and their reactions towards you will depend on your reputation with that faction. Most importantly, you can take missions and talk with them. You can ask them about the various different factions, about events and locations, thus gaining some background information on the events that are taking place or that previously took place.

If you pick up a quest you can check it on your Journal. Here you can also see failed and completed quests. Any progress made within a certain quest will also be shown here as well as the dialogue and story behind it.

Gameplay:The overall gameplay is really fun. You move your ship with W, A, S, D, Q and E and you aim with your mouse. Combat is in real time and hip movement and maneuverability is really important here, because weapons on ships have an arc of fire and so, you should try to keep yourself out of the enemy range. This allows for some sort of agile combat that requires you to keep both your ship moving and your weapons aimed towards the opponent at the same time.

Flying around on your spaceship and fighting enemies requires you to keep an eye on some key things. Your ship has several meters such as energy, shield and structure, as well as fuel which is pretty self-explanatory. The shield bar obviously represents what percentage of shield you currently have on your ship, if this reaches 0 you’ll start taking structural damage and if you manage to not get hit during a certain time, your shield will eventually recharge. The energy meter on the other hand acts as if it is your stamina bar. Firing weapons and mining, for example, uses energy so you can’t just spam your weapons and have to time your shots correctly. That said, you’re also required to be at a full stop when mining, and the same goes for when you’re looting a container dropped by an enemy.

Combat and movement aside, the game pretty much plays as you want to play it. You can attack friendly vessels, you can hunt down pirates or any other faction or you can just make your fortune by mining asteroids and selling the ore at a nearby space station. You can help characters and join a faction and help them achieve their ultimate goal, or you can just ignore everyone and just do your own thing.

Verdict:Open sandbox world, choose how to play your own game. e.g. be a pacifist or a soldier
Nice looking visuals with 3D effects
Tons of ship customization
Mod support
Fun combat
Chill music
Dead multiplayer
I HIGHLY recommend this game to fans of spacefaring, space sandbox and space sims. If you enjoyed games like SPAZ or Space Rangers I’m sure you’ll have a great time with VoidExpanse!

reviewText:
Ah, Space... it seems like space games are having a whole new renaissance these days. VoidExpanse is one of those games that sounds very simple, and even looks very simple. So, you start up a new game, and start mucking about, and then realize what feels like half an hour later that you've somehow lost several hours. The skill trees, the different ship hulls that actually FEEL like different ships, instead of just looking like them, and the fun of the combat... I'll be blunt: This game isn't a shiny polished AAA title. It has some quirks, particularly in the dialogue. However, VoidExpanse gets it right where it actually counts: It's fun to play, and the developers have a love for the game and community that shows in their continuing efforts to constantly improve and even expand the game. Lurler and co at Atomic Torch have built not just an excellent 2D space sandbox, they've built a devoted community, and the beginning of a reputation as a stand-up group of talented developers that actually care about their fans.
Putting the developer and community aside, though, let me explain the game, since that's what's actually being reviewed. Firstly, you won't play the same exact game twice, even if the main story(ies) don't radically change. VoidExpanse is a 2D space sandbox kind of game in the vein of Space Rangers, Solar Winds, or (to a lesser degree) S.P.A.Z. You start off customizing you character portrait with a number of options (which can be expanded via workshop), pick a trade/class which will allot your starting skills, and then start off in a low-tech backwater space base. The game has a pretty low learning curve, and piloting your ship will become natural very quickly.
There are two primary things that will determine your playstyle:
1) your skills, which will establish everything from what kinds of ship hulls you can pilot, how well you can pilot them, what kinds of weapons you can use, how well you can use those weapons, the types of trade and dialogue options available, what types of equipment you can use, and how efficient everything from mining lasers to fuel are.
2) your ship hull, which will determine cargo capacity, speed, maneuvering, and types of weapon mounts.
You can spend your time just following the main story, and only doing odd jobs, trading, or mining as needed to upgrade your equipment as needed, or you can bum about as a space miner and make your fortune hunting rare ores to sell to the highest bidder. You can establish trade routes, become a bounty hunter... it's up to you. Granted, the actual variety of missions can be limited, but there are a few standout side missions that are truly unique.
If you like the idea of a 2D space sandbox, they don't get much better than this. It has some flaws, but it delivers a solid and engaging experience, and is just loads of fun to play.
Oh yeah... and you can play online. Just saying.
8/10

reviewText:
Introduction:
VoidExpanse is a Top-Down, Open World Space RPG with a branching story line. With the ability to define how big your universe may grow, this game can take you quite some time to fully explore. As an added bonus, since the universe is procedurally generated, you will never experience the same universe twice in a row.

The game has a beautiful backdrop which can make each system look and feel somewhat unique. The character portraits being randomized for non-key NPCs also add a refreshing new feel to each replay of the game. The ships have enough detail and varietie for this style of art to make them visually appealing as well. The sounds are fairly standard, but they work fine for this game.

Gameplay:
There are many different character options to choose from at the start of the game. You customize your character portrait as well as your starting Class. Starting Classes just give you a head start down their related Skill Trees, however as you play, it is completely feasible that you could max out every Skill Tree.

Skill trees are the games way of locking you out of content that would otherwise make you too powerful to start with. Luckily, early on it is easy to gain levels so you can quickly unlock better ships and weapons that you may need to progress. This system does have a bit of a drawback though. When playing through one of the factions, I was told I had to destroy enemy space stations using a custom missile that I was issued. This is where a major issue occurred for me. Since this was my second play through, I had opted to play as a miner/trader who operated a freighter. My freighter was only a middle tier ship that had medium pulse lasers. My ship wasn’t designed to fight and didn’t even have a bay that could support a missile let alone a level 3 one. It was simply equipped to defend against a single attacker or a few lower class attackers while making its escape. I had almost maxed out my energy weapons, Industry (mining), Social (trade skills) and my Piloting (to enhance cargo space and speed) skills. This meant I had not focused anything on the other weapon types or heavier hulls. I had bought myself a very heavy beam only Death Bringer ship for making runs into the Alien space and the heavy pulse weapons for it… but didn’t have the skills to fly it yet, was still working on that. At this point I knew I was either screwed or I was in for one heavy grind. I needed to be able to get enough skill points to unlock level 3 Missiles, heavier hulls and the money to buy the ship and everything I needed to equip it properly. I had to do tedious filler missions given by the random stations while doing mining runs to raise the experience and money required. Days later, I finally had my heavy ship loaded to the teeth with everything including my missile. This made blowing up those Alien space stations even more satisfying because of the effort I had to put in to it.

As mentioned, there are plenty of customization options for this game. There are quite a few different ships to choose from, each with its own loadout slots and statistics. It would be nice if there were a few omni-slot ships that let you customize it exactly how you want, but using the ones already in game works. There is an even wider assortment of weapons to choose from plus the critical ship systems and subsystems that can also be customized. The numbers of configurations you can make are almost limitless. This, along with the aforementioned procedural generation of the selectable size universe helps to make each replay unique. One feature I like is the fact that your character isn’t a miracle worker. If you find yourself a better weapon floating in the debris of the ship you just vaporized, you can’t just slap it on to your ship and fly off merrily on your way. You have to get to a space station and dock with it in order to adjust critical components of your ship. Really the only thing your pilot can do while out and about is to reload the consumable things such as hull repair or shield energy. This is a rather good decision on the Developers part as it adds realism to the game. It actually makes it a little more exciting to know that if you don’t survive the trip back to the nearest space station, your new found prize will be lost when you explode.

Why might you want to replay the game? Well after the introductory area, there are three factions all looking to take you in as a recruit. Once you determine which faction you want to join you can seek out their recruitment officer. The recruitment officer of course doesn’t let just anyone join, you must prove yourself worthy of their cause. This is where the story lines diverge. Once you are in a faction you will have to stick with that choice until the end of the game. The end mission will be changed to suit the faction you are a member of, be it to blow the aliens out of their part of the galaxy, find a way back home, or finding a way to pacify alien hostility.

Unfortunately, once you finish the starting area and do all the efforts required to join a faction, when you are really ready to get going, the game hits the home stretch and ends shortly after. This game relies on the fact you have to do the generic missions, hunt enemy (or if you are a jerk, friendly ships) and mine in order to gain experience and money. This works great early on but becomes a very heavy and barely rewarding grind in the later portion of the game. The deeper into the Alien territories you go, the heavier their resistance becomes. You will quickly find yourself swarmed with ships at a far higher level than you. Another issue I had is if you take a jump gate then look at your map too long, you will find a swarm of pirates zoning in behind you and almost killing you before you can move. Death is also unforgiving and what it takes from you is based on what difficulty setting you took at the beginning of the game when generating your universe.

Another thing that pads out gameplay is travel time. Often you will find the mission provider and the mission system are separated by a vast distance. You then need to fly there with the assistance of Jump gates to link systems together… but unfortunately there is not usually a direct route. You will have to pass through each system that separates you and your destination dealing with any hostiles that may decide to attack you. You also need to watch your fuel levels or you will find yourself having to limp home at a low speed.

Overall, there is plenty to do in VoidExpanse. It is a fun enough game that you might find yourself replaying it just to see how the story ends for each of the factions.

Pro:
Highly customizable ships, equipment, and weapons
Procedurally Generated Universe so it is different each time you play
Multiple Factions helps enhance replayability
Play it how you want for the most part. Be a trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, a pirate or any combination of the above Cons:
Must do introductory level each time you do a fresh restart
A lot of grinding is required to survive late game
Repetitive filler quests used solely to help you level up and gain money. You find the same few quest types no matter where you go. Kill this pirate, rescue this crew, or deliver this cargo
A lot of flying around between systems to get from point A to B then back to A again. Very time consuming and gets old. Would be nice if you could just radio in that you finished the mission rather than flying half way across the galaxy again just to turn it in
Able to spend skill points in such a way it can mess you over later in the game. It’s fixable but you will need to grind to do it

reviewText:
Sandbox-esque space combat

Top down space combat has been done before, lets get that out of the way.  From some of my earliest video game memories playing Star Control till recently with S.P.A.Z. this game follows a familiar combat formula.  But that's not a bad thing in any way.  Strafe, steer, and blast your way through your enemies with a bunch of changeable loadouts, ships, and different classes of 'hulls'  (the skeleton for the ship you'll use).  What makes this game great is the sandbox element.  It doesn't tell you what to do, but it does have branching quests.  Of course you're free to completely ignore them and just while away the hours mining asteroids if you so chooose.  Go to war with one of the factions in the game, or try to eliminate the alien menace that dominates a large chunk of the galaxy.  Ultimately it's up to you.

If there's one big complaint about the game it's that it feels a little empty.  You hit a wall around your late 30s where the experience points seem to take a lot longer and the upgrades are much further apart then you'd like.  With some of them being only say, a 3% to your cruising speed, leveling feels pretty underwhelming after a while.  Thankfully you get experience for doing pretty much anything in this game.  Also combatting the emptiness is the modding community which already has full game overhauls, rebalanced skill trees, new hulls, new weapons, new quests, and more.  I'd like to see even more modding for this game personally, as more content can only improve an already great game.

If you like this style of game, it's well worth the purchase price.

YES! This is what I was looking for! Open sandbox space sim where you choose your own path! Oh man I don't even know where to start, so I'll give a summary of my playthrough so far:

I fired it up, set it to normal and rand-gen'd some bloke to play as (ended up with a guy with a pink mohawk and a hawaiian shirt. The absurdity has grown on me a bit). And I hit it right off. The interface and controls weren't too intuitive, but not too cryptic either. I had it pretty well figured out in under 5 minutes, and started working for the tutorial guy. And he taught me asteriod mining and mission running and trading and some basic combat and and then gave me a run down of what's going on in the sector then it was a pat on the butt and off you go. That's it. You get to kick it into high drive within.. 30 minutes? Of the game start.

And the depth of the game is great. There's 5 factions, only one of which I know well, one I have a good idea of, and one that's a mystery to me, one's pirates and the last one is the EVIL ALIENS (TM). You level up and allocate your XP points to your skills, which go all the way from asteriod mining up to PEW PEW BANG and everything inbetween. And I mean everything. There's some really weird skills in there.

Combat can leap between fairly routine to very surprising, depending on how high you keep your guard up. I was doing pretty damn well off the start beating up pirates and mining rocks, so I got pretty full of myself and headed into a fairly dangerous system to rack up some XP.

Ha ha they beat my ♥♥♥ like a drum. I needed a bigger ship.

Now, ship size isn't terribly noticable. I suppose because they'd have to zoom the screen out a lot to make a difference. It's basically just better hull, and better weapon placement. Which is a huge thing in combat. It's not so much the size of your gun, but whether or not you can bring it to bear! Some turrets point forwards, to the sides, out the back, etc! And also you have to match them up to their type of weapon. Energy/Kinetic/Missile/Mine. So, each ship has its own style of combat.

Ship equipment is fairly straightforward. You want bigger and better, but you need to carefully manage how much fuel and power your fuel tank and reactor can provide. The thing I like is the fact you don't need to strip old ships for parts. No, your hull is literally just another equipment slot. You just swap it out and bang, new hull same equipment.

Very enjoyable and challanging at times. It's going to see hundreds of hours from me.

reviewText:
This game is very addictive. Seems a little simplistic and the controls take a bit of getting used to. I crashed quite a bit until I got the hang of it down and I still am not very good at shooting down ships without a lot of misses but I have been really addicted to this game since I started playing it.

Your a space ship captain and you fly around different sectors completing jobs, mining materials, and fighting bad guys to make money and upgrade your ship. There is a story line but to be honest I really haven't been paying much attention to it as I've been more focused on getting new ships and the best equipment for them. I've almost gotten the heavy cruisers, which is the heaviest ship in the game unlocked and I'm excited for it.

I've found that mining is the easiest and safest way to make money and is almost always necessary as fuel to fly costs money so you can't just go from station to station without either fighting or mining to keep at least enough money to fuel your ship. Fuel is expensive so I recommend upgrading your mining equipment quickly so you can get the best materials so you an offset costs quickly so you have more money for upgrades.

I definitely want to note that the developer is very active with this game. I happen to have started playing the day they released a patch that broke the game. I was stuck in the starting system and couldn't complete the tutorial to leave. They had the issue resolved in less than a day so while it wasn't the best experience, at least they are active and pay attention when issues arise.

I haven't played multiplayer and probably won't as I'm more into the single player experience so I have no recommendations on how that works out but I bet it would be a pretty good time.

I definitely recommend this game if you are interested in a game where you are given a ship and almost free reign to make your fortune and get the most powerful equipment you can.

Only negative I can think of that I ran into other than the update issue is that sometimes you have to end up with issues because the game is so intense in regards to fuel. I ran into a few times where I got stranded because a few systems in a row didn't have any place to refuel. Recommend you keep some power cells handy just in case. Some people may also find some issues with the slow pace of mining as well. Each instance takes about 5 seconds and you are just sitting there. Doesn't seem like much but when you only get 60 pieces every time you mine, it can get tedius to fill a ship with a big cargo hold.... this is especially prevailent when you are going for a specific ore for a mission and are only getting 2 to 4 each time and you need 350 to complete the mission.

Definitely a great game though and I recommend it for anyone that likes space ship games. Definitely not X2 as far as economy goes but its still a great game.

reviewText:
This game melds great elements of a Star Control II, Pirates!, and Space Rangers 2 experience. While it doesn't have the depth of any of the aforementioned, it still puts them all together into a solid, tight, entertaining package over and above its price tag.

The RPG elements are simple but meaningful (the emphasis on a specific player and attributes is welcome and refreshing)

The buying/selling/mining is simple but satisfying

The combat is standard fare to a degree, but I do like the strong correlation between purchasing better items and seeing them *act* like better items on your ship.

The pacing is strong (the tutorial/initial missions are not elaborate, just directed enough to teach you what you need to know in poignant and terse terms).

For its current price, it's eons above other fare. I've heard it compared to Endless Sky, but I disagree strongly with the parallels. Endless Sky is a baby carriage compared to the Maserati that is VoidExpanse.

reviewText:
introductionVoidExpanse is a interesting space game with RPG nad open world elements thrown into the mix. For a open world game like this, you would want there to be a lot to explore and stuff to find. VoidExpanse does that, with the open world freedom that this game delivers it really gives you a lot of freedom to explore.

GameplayThis game seems to have all the right elements that a open world, RPG game should reallly have. Massive areas to explore at your own free will, there is no limitation or blocked off sections to limit the open world experience of this game. There is so much to explore, the amount of quests there are in this game is sure to keep you playing for hours upon hours. There is a extensive and impressive upgrading system in this game, which also ties in with the huge amount of researching that can also help you along whilst you play this game. The fighting in this game is pretty basic, with simple mechanics that you will have gained, weapons, armour, and sheilds. The sheilds and some of the weapons use a yellow energy bar, weapons such as lazers will require you to use energy to shoot. The bigger and more powerful lazers in the game will require more energy, and therefore you may have to wait for your energy to recharge after battling a few enemies. On the other hand, you can use weapons such as missiles and guns which use there own supply of ammo. Although I found that you would run out of ammo for missiles rather quickly, and would have to dock at a nearby station in order to restock your rockets. There does seem to be a multiplayer mode built into the game, although it seems that you can't bring your ship from single player into other servers to play multiplayer. This isn't much of a problem, as playign the game single player doesn't really limit or change much when you have a couple of others helping you in multiplayer servers. At first this game doesn't really seem to be a grind, you are happily just accepting quests, completeing more and leveling up as you play along. But it does seem that after a while of playing this game, it just becomes more of a grind to level up to gain skill points that you want. The missions do start to get boring, as they seem to repeat themselves with recon missions and exploring astroids and such.

The overworld itself looks very space like, with all of these galaxies that you can see in the background as you drive your ship throughout the world. The background images are quite dull and some of them really nicely constrast with the dark background. Each area you visit doesn't feel the same as before, there is a rather nice variety of different colours and backgrounds throughout the game. The graphics of each of the ships that you can get are rather nice looking, some of them have a nice light at the back of the ship which sort of glows behind you slightly as you fly around space.

Pro+ Open world
+ Different types of weapons
+ Single player & Multiplayer story mode
+ Nice graphics
+ Trading cards & achievements

Cons- After a while it begins more of a grind
- The missions get a little samey after a while
- Can't transfer single player ship to multiplayer

Result / Final thoughtsFor what VoidExpanse is asking for, this game is definitely worth it for space and RPG fans. It's really fun and enjoyable to play, with tons of content and some simplistic fighting mechanics. The graphics in the game are fairly nice with the combination of your ship and the enemy ships that are attacking you. If your a space or RPG fan I highly recommened this game to you.

Rating: 9/10

Void Expanse has consumed a lot of my time since I first discovered it, and I regret none of it!

This Space-RPG has a randomly generated open world, with three distinct plot lines to follow, as well as a fair number of side quests and activities: e.g. bounty hunting, trading & mining. The world has a gritty, yet tongue in cheek feel to it. And cleansing the system of Xengatarn aliens will keep you going for ages!

The biggest plus, though, in my opinion, is the availability for modding. The devs openly encourage it, and have built the game around this, making it one of the easiest games to mod.

Outside of the game, the dev team are quick to respond to any bug reports or questions, listen to any comments, and are generally very helpful.

In my opinion: money well spent.

Want to roleplay Sweden and fight pirates and stay neutral? That's also an option!

reviewText:
I've played this game for like 10 hours now the first day I purchased it. Clearly I must like it.

You have a good reason to like it too. This game reminds me of EVE Online only in an arcade format. There is a single player mode and a multiplayer mode.

In this game you are a space adventurer struggling to deal with the aftermath of a disasterous war where your part of space is cut of after the Federation (no relation to Star Trek) destroys a stargate leading back to the heart of intersteller civilization, surrounded by a scant number of merchants, fellow stranded space adventurers, and aliens and pirates who want to kill you.

This is a sandbox game. Yes you are given quests to do to earn currency, but you get to do what you want. You buy better ships for combat, exploration and mining, making sure you got the best weapons and devices snapped on. You loot destroyed enemies, or you get looted if they destroy you. There are three play modes, the first one (I'm familiar with) is you respawn after you die but you lose your loot. The last one is permadeath where you really do need balls of iron, because when you die, you die.

You get to play in a faction, each one has advantages. There are six if memory serves. The single player mode stores a galaxy you can set the size of with a slider. I haven't tried multiplayer only because I just got the game. When I play multiplayer, I'll update my review.  Even if I hate multiplayer it won't change my recommendation because the single player mode is worth the money paid alone, with or without the discount.

The ships you get to play range from small fighters to large warships but they cost money and, if you are an EVE Online player like me, you really need to fly only what you can afford to lose. While the hulls are limited to what you can slap on for hardpoints, there is room for some customization at the device part and some hardpoints allow either a beam or a ballistic weapon.

You get to customize your character you play, gender, hairstyle, skin color, eye type, nose type, mouth type, accessory...it's limited but I'm sure the devs will add more choices...yes, that was a hint.

There's a class and skill tree where you can tailor your character's development as the character earns levels. You get to choose a class, miner, combat, etc, with some of the basic skill points aready filled on, and then as you level you earn skill points where you can allocate to parts of the skill tree, like efficiency in energy usage for firing weapons and shield operation, or tracking weapon turret time. If you played EVE Online this is going to be familar to you.

The ships move similarly like EVE Online's propulsion physics, meaning there's no Newtonian mechanics here. You coast to a stop after you end propulsion, of which there are two, RCS thrusters and main engine. In this game you move directionally using the W A S and D key and laterally using Q and E. Ships use a form of fuel which is converted to energy that is then used to power weapons, defense systems, gadgets and so on.

The game may crash in singleplayer mode from time to time but because it autosaves when you go from system to system, or dock, it's not a big inconvienence.

Recommendation? This is a beautifully visual game where every control and menu makes sense being where they should be. It does not require a killer graphics card and even old laptops can play it with the tweaking of the graphics controls. Buy it. It's a fun space romp in a desolate galaxy where anything can happen.

reviewText: Great game for the 1st 20 hours or so. After that it becomes brutally hard (in an unbalanced manner, not in a hard-but-fun Dark Souls manner), and as some have noted the mid/end-game is lacking in content. In mid to end-game your RPG skills/ship progression comes to a crawl as difficulty ramps up very suddenly (too suddenly IMHO) while remaining repetitive (combat becomes harder but there's not anything really 'new' to it - compare this to S.P.A.Z. which introduces a whole new combat dynamic (the zombies) mid-game, which keeps things fresh.) Combat at level 5 feels much like combat when you're level 40, it's just much harder. So after a while the game starts to feel like a real grind.\n\nThis game is like a cross between a prettier S.P.A.Z. and a more action-oriented Space Rangers 2, albeit in a 'light' form. It feels superior to S.P.A.Z.  for the first 10-20 hours because the basic combat mechanics work very well - I love using mines, and it's fun to find just the right weapon combo amongst a pretty good selection of weapons. However VoidExpanse runs out of steam at about level 35-40. Some of the quests are interesting but a most of them get very grindy/cliche/repetitive fast. Still, production values are higher than with SPAZ or Space Rangers 2, and combat is a lot of fun, at least for a while. If the developers put in more mid to end-game content, more high-end ship components, and did more balancing in mid/late game, and added more features like the ability to hire henchman (sometimes you're given a henchman, but it'd be great to hire and manage them at will) then this game would be AWESOME! As it is, like I said it's fun for the first 20 hours, so for $15 I got my money's worth and I give it a thumbs up.

reviewText:
The game could use a little more content and polish, but it is worth the asking price. I've only run into 2 technical problems, a pathfinding bug which is very minor, and the occasional crash (irregular, sometimes it crashes at launch, other times I can play 4-8 hours without a problem).

Game uses an Asteroids (for those who remember that game) style physics system, which means that when you head in a direction, you continue to drift. You will stop eventually, but not quickly enough to warrant changing this description. Personally, I've never been fond of this style, but that is a matter of preference and hopefully a moder will give us a choice on it.

There are several tiers of ships and weapons, and there is a decent amount of customization. Ship selection isn't vast, but it is enough to have a comfortable amount of choice, and its highly moddable with ship hull mods being the most common at this point (yt-1300, and star trek mods already out). Weapon selection could also use a little more expansion as well, but again, its enough to give a decent amount of choice.

There are multiple campaign routes to take, one for each faction except neutral. Optional quests are sparse, but cover the basics, trading, mining, escort, courier, and bounty (mod available to allow the player to choose which they take).

Game could definitely be fleshed out more, and a lot of things are underway, but in its current condition, it is worth the asking price. It doesn't blow me away, but neither do I regret buying it.

Game does not support gamepads, or any other control method besides mouse and keyboard at this time.

Also, since this is an issue to some people, you will have to make an account for the game. Doing so consists of giving a username that is not already taken, and nothing more. This is done to make multiplayer run smoothly, but multiplayer is purely optional, creating a username, however, is not. No personal information is requested.

This is still a very unpolished game.  I'm still experiencing a lot cases where the game crashes on start, and occasionally during gameplay.

The combat system is OK, but there's few quests and the ones that exists are the tired old 'fetch me X number of Ys', kill this enemy, rescue this NPC.  Some of the faction quests actually involve dialog, and those are OK, but too few and too shallow. There's very little plot in this game.

The backgrounds, planets and ships and space stations are definitely beautiful, there's no lack of pretty graphics.

Issues with the Gameplay:

Autopilot will run into stationary objects like space junk and asteroids.  It's bad enough that it plots courses through groups of enemy ships, but it's a space game. Even if you're only allowed to move in a 2D plane the autopilot could go under or over those obsticles, or just plot a course around.

SWARMS of PIRATES EVERYWHERE.  There's just too freakin' many.  Tone it down, especially in space controlled by other factions.

I've had the game for 2 days, and I've already got all the best equipment in the whole game.  It appears that the rest of the game will just be an annoying grindfest and the tenuous plot isn't enough to make me want to finish.

Also a recommendation, just one jumpgate per system.  That gate should be able to send you to the other connected systems. So when you get a fetch quest you don't get blown up while the autopilot crashes you into asteroids while a dozen pirates rain fire on your ship. Then you can reward curious players that take the time to explore a system by hiding interesting things in it (and no, the alien relics that are only good for science points don't count. Interesting stuff, more stories, easter eggs, etc.)

And more plot...some of the faction quests were nice, but there needs to be more!

reviewText:
VoidExpanse is an arcade version of Escape Velocity.  It's a much shallower world, with a larger focus on action.  Pirates/hostiles aren't an anomaly, they’re scattered across every map like koopas and goombas, they’ll jump into any fight even when they’re horribly outmatched.

They have added XP for pilot leveling, and a skill tree to specialize your pilot, which is a nice improvement. Staying true to the more arcade feel, these rewards come fast and furious.  I’ve put in 5 hours (5 learning hours, so plenty of time reading tool tips and trying to figure things out) and am already level 35.

The ship upgrade process is also streamlined.  The hull is just one more slotted upgrade (although it does change which weapon slots are available), and there’s no weight attribute to balance things out.  So you never need to decide how to optimize one ship, while saving for another, you just grab an upgrade for whichever slot you can.  Not a lot of decisions to make, you just get the next level of your radar/fuel tank/grappler, and if you happen to switch out hulls, they stay with you.  Like the pilot leveling, these upgrades come fast.  You never really reach the limits of your ship, and set a goal for a better ship, you’re just constantly upgrading everything before you hit the limit.  I don’t know that I need a new generator, but one’s offered, so you upgrade it. You don’t really have any sense of accomplishment.

The factions are also very simplified.  There seem to be 6 total, and you're basically chosing between 2.  Pirates; Aliens that are trying to wipe out humanity; people that worship said aliens; neutrals; and then the two choices: Freedom or Order.  So far, it seems like progression of these quest lines are pretty much on rails.  Helping Order doesn’t seem to make Freedom like me any less.

There’s a nice dialog system in game, where you can ask anyone about any topic you like.  While the system’s nice, it doesn’t seem to be very fleshed out.  Most everyone just repeats the tutorial for most options, and there doesn’t seem to be much of a reward for being thorough or going deep.

Quests are fairly simplified, too.  There are bounty missions to kill one particular pirate in the system you’re in (and he’s marked on the radar).  You can do rescue missions to a piece of debris in your system.  Then there are escort missions and package deliveries, which go to different systems, but there’s no concept of time, so you can just pick up as many as you want and drop them off when you happen to get to the system. There’s a cargo quest I’ve been offered a couple times, but they warn you you need a lot of space (unspecified) so I’ve declined it.  The last generic quest I’ve been offered is a mining contract, which is always for the same amount of the same mineral.   Much like the dialog system, it seems like the quests really need to be fleshed out.

In true arcade form, death is only a minor inconvenience.  Your body’s cloned (the cost is equivalent to about 1 quest reward) and your ship, it turns out, is fully insured. You lose your non-quest inventory, and that’s it.

The ship to ship fighting has some interesting mechanics, different weapons having different tracking speeds, being able to assign different weapons to different firing groups.  I think it suffers for the camera being way too close.  If a ship comes in from the top of your screen, it’s already within range of your weapons, and is only ~8 ship lengths away. If things were zoomed out, so you could play with the edge of your weapons range, it opens up a lot more tactical dogfighting.

To sum up, it’s Arcade Escape Velocity, for all the positives and negatives that “Arcade” brings with it. I’d appreciate a bit more depth at a more deliberate pace, but VoidExpanse really leans towards the arcade feel.  Hopefully they expand on the dialog tree and quest options as time goes on.  And maybe at later levels you’ll actually know you want/need an upgrade before you’ve already obtained it.

Last note: I’m playing on a 5k iMac and even after lowering the video options it gets choppy in cruise mode.  It also requires a monoframework package install, and I’ve had a few freezes.

Holding out hope for improvements, but as is I can't recommend this game.

I appreciate the work that goes into an Indie title, but that doesn't mean I'm automatically going to recommend it because it's Indie and an impressive effort for that alone.  I don't regret the purchase simply because it's a 'value' title.  If I had to choose again, I would have saved the money and spent it elsewhere.

Disclaimer: I have not beaten this game - but in 7 hours of play I did get to level 34 and have explored a large number of sectors.  I'm going to continue for a while and will revise my review if anything compelling happens to alter my feelings.

The Good:
Ships are customizable
Open galaxy to explore
Well planned character skill tree
Attractive backdrops and workable graphics
Devices make for some worthwhile combos - like mining for ore and using it for repairs
Autopilot works well
A solid Indie effortThe Meh:
Weapons aren't well balanced and lasers rule combat
Enemies don't aggro unless you're within a short range
Enemies largely sit in one spot and wait for you to come kill them
Missions and combat are extremely repetitive
A fair number of possible ships and equipment to choose from, but only a few worth using
Autopilot used extensively to get around - you watch the game play itself while you travel
Levels come pretty quickly and end up feeling less important for thatThe Bad:
The universe feels largely unalive and soulless - it feels like a paint the by numbers adventure kit
Combat is soggy as you have to compensate for ship momentum and weapon arcs
AI Allies" are dumb as bricks and very much in the way instead of helping"
